qas.question: What should you do if you have a fever?
What is the name of the washcloth that you apply to the area of the shot?
What is the name of the person who can give you medicine?

paragraphs.context:
cdc.gov/coronavirus
What to Expect after Getting a COVID-19 Vaccine
The COVID-19 shot may cause side effects in some people. Side effects should go away in a few days. On the arm where you got the shot:
• Pain
• Redness
• Swelling
If you are sore where you got the shot:
• Apply a clean, cool, wet washcloth over the area
• Use or move your arm gently
If you have a fever:
• Drink a lot of water
• Get plenty of rest
• Dress lightly
If you have pain, headache, or fever, ask a healthcare provider (or facility
staff) if you can have medicine.

qas.question: What should you wear when you are in a correctional facility?
How far away from others should you stay from others?
What should go away in a few days?
How long does it take for your body to build protection after a vaccination?

paragraphs.context:
Even after your COVID-19 vaccination, when you are in a correctional facility, it’s important
to continue wearing a well-fitting mask, try to stay at least 6 feet away from others as
much as possible, and wash your hands often. Side effects may make
you feel a little sick or
even make it hard to
do daily activities, but
they should go away
in a few days. vaccination rates and
ensure that staff and
residents stay up to date
on their COVID-19 vaccines. COVID-19 vaccines may
not fully protect you
until a week or two after
your final shot. It takes
time for your body to
build protection after
any vaccination.

qas.question: How long does it take for the redness or pain to get better?

paragraphs.context:
Ask the facility healthcare provider (or facility staff) for help if:
• The redness or pain where you got the shot gets worse after 24 hours
• Your side effects are worrying you
• Your side effects do not seem to be going away after a few days
In the rest of your body:
• Fever
• Chills
• Tiredness
• Headache
• Muscle pain
• Nausea
COMMON SIDE EFFECTS
HELPFUL TIPS
REMEMBER

About COVID-19 Vaccines
COVID-19 vaccines are safe and effective. CDC recommends COVID-19 vaccines for everyone 6 months and older and boosters
for everyone 5 years and older, if eligible. Learn about the different vaccines available. To find a COVID-19 vaccine near you: Search vaccines.gov, text your zip
code to 438829, or call 1-800-232-0233 to find COVID-19 vaccine locations near you. Benefits of Getting Vaccinated

qas.question: What can happen if you get a COVID-19 vaccine and you think you might be having a severe allergic reaction to a vaccine?

answers.text: seek immediate medical care by calling 911

qas.question: What is rare but can happen?
What should you do if you think you might be allergic to the COVID-19 vaccine?

answers.text: seek immediate medical care by calling 911

paragraphs.context:
10/30/22, 9:31 AM Allergic Reactions after COVID-19 Vaccination | CDC
Español | Other Languages
Allergic Reactions after COVID-19 Vaccination
If You Are Having a Severe Allergic Reaction to a COVID-19
Vaccine
Severe allergic reactions to vaccines are rare but can happen. If you get a COVID-19 vaccine and you think you might be
having a severe allergic reaction after leaving the vaccination provider site, seek immediate medical care by calling 911. A severe allergic reaction can cause:
difficulty breathing or wheezing,
a drop in blood pressure,
swelling of the tongue or throat, or
a generalized rash or hives, which may include mucus membranes.
